text: was a great presentation this will be the last of the recorded presentations for the symposium and last video on this part one stream we have jf clotier an experiment in artificial agency an experiment in artificial agency
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm Jean-Francois Cloutier.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm a research fellow at the Active Influence Institute, and I do research in cognitive robotics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One of the principal questions I ask myself is, what does it take, at a minimum, for an autonomous robot to learn to survive in a world it knows initially almost nothing about?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Other questions which follow are,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Can a robot act for its own reasons?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Does it have agency?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Can its agency be programmed?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And would such a robot be an active inference agent?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The one way to find out is to actually build an artificial agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And by artificial agent, I mean a sense-making, adaptive, and self-directed robot.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this project is a continuation of a personal project that I started quite a few years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And three years ago, here's where I was.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I had a Lego robot with quite a few sensors, like ultrasonic sensors, infrared sensor, a color sensor, illuminance sensor, motors of different types.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: All this running from a Raspberry Pi with a board that provides an interface between the Raspberry Pi and the various Lego motors and sensors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the robot also had a 360-degree beacon that allowed one robot to see another through the other robot's 360-degree beacon seeker.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So let's look at them in action.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I named them Carl and Andy for, I think, quite obvious reasons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Carl had gone through quite a lot of training runs, so it was better at finding the food, which is the piece of paper on the floor, with a beacon providing the scent, the attractive scent.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We can see that Andy is having a bit of a hard time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And they see each other so that if one robot starts acting panicky, which they do if they collide too often, the other will notice the pattern of movement.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if one robot makes a beeline, then the other robot will perceive that and say, aha, that's where the food is, and try to move in the same direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we see them moving about.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and trying to gather the food and eating the food.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And Carl is clearly more apt at this task than Andy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And what they've learned through various trials are the policies that are most successful at finding the food.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So that's where I was three years ago.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The way I implemented the cognitive capabilities, quote unquote, of these robots was based on an architectural model described by Marvin Minsky in his book, The Society of Mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This architecture posits that interesting behaviors emerge from many simple actors
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: that interact in simple ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we're looking at cognition as a collective intelligence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The implementation was a hierarchy of these simple processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I call them cognition actors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And they formed an abstraction hierarchy with, at the very bottom, cognition actors that simply wrap sensors and effectors, motors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And then at the very bottom, we have cognition actors that care about very simple things like the location of food.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Then at a higher level, information obtained from the food location cognition actor feeds into the food approach cognition actor.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this one tries to figure out, am I getting closer to the food?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And so forth and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Other cognition actors are concerned with avoiding collisions and avoiding dark places.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, each cognition actor, as I said, is a separate process.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And each such process does very simple things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It makes predictions about what it will observe next.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It then updates its beliefs based on predictions that were successful or prediction errors received, and then selects a policy randomly in the beginning, but then based on what was successful in the past, and applies that policy, acts, and then decides, and then predicts what the next incoming sensations will be, and so forth and so on, essentially implementing an OODA loop.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: observe, orient, decide, and act.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's one big problem, though, that this society of mine, this hierarchy of cognition actors, is predefined.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's hard-coded.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For each robot, it's the same.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The only thing that's learned is what policy is more effective over time, based on experience.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The robot acted for my reasons, for the programmer's reasons, not its own.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The robots had autonomy, but no agency.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In 2022, I joined the Active Inference Institute and continued this project under the symbolic cognitive robotics tag.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I asked myself, what if a robot started with only a rudimentary society of mind?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What if it didn't have that pre-built society of mind, this hierarchy of cognition actors?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It started only with the most basic ones, the ones that wrap sensors and motors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Then the society of mind would grow from experiencing autonomous engagement.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the robot would start
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and with all these very basic prior cognition actors for sensing and affecting, and then would create new cognition actors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And these cognition actors would be very, very simple in the sense that they would take their sensations from the sensors themselves and would act by
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: engaging the motors, and then observe how it changes its perceptions of, say, color or distance and whatnot, etc.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, cognition actors would be added to the society of mind, brought them up to make sense of observations and actions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, each new cognition actor would select an umwelt,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: composed of cognition actors one level below.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And how do we know that a particular level of cognition actors in this growing hierarchy is complete?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's when all cognition actors one level below belong to an umwelt.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, it would not only grow, but it would also shrink, because whenever cognition actors were recognized to be hopelessly ineffective,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: they would eventually be removed and new cognition actors would take their place.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the hope would be that as this cognition hierarchy grows, becomes more competent, we would have a robot that starts acting intelligently and in survivable ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the society of mind would grow, shrink, and evolve as needed to survive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now that's a key point here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is an implementation of a form of moral computing.
